segments.text: April 20, 1989 at Texas A&M concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I'm going to donate this tape to Texas A&M oral history collection in the university archives.
Is that okay with you?
Yes, that's fine.
Okay.
Why did you volunteer to go to Vietnam and what was the date of your first tour?
I did not initially volunteer to go to Vietnam.
I went at the convenience of the service.
But I volunteered for the military
Why I volunteered for the military was simply probably the Southern tradition of I saw the uniform and it really jazzed me up.
Basically, I and three friends went down and volunteered.
When I got into the service in 1967, the manpower needs were pretty strong.
in Vietnam and the military just arbitrarily picked a number of us and sent us to Vietnam and that's how I got there the first tour.
What was your understanding of the purpose of the war before you went?
My understanding before I went of the purpose of the war is that we were trying to stop the communist advance in Southeast Asia.
much the domino theory stuff.
We were there to make the people of South Vietnam free and simultaneously keep the communists from taking over all of Asia.
And what were your opinions of the president before the war?
Opinions of LBJ?
Really, to tell you the truth, I don't think I even had an opinion of LBJ other than the fact that he was
The president, he was from Texas, and that was about it.
I had no opinion one way or the other, to tell you the truth.
Okay, how old were you?
Let's see, in 1967.
Eighteen.
How did your opinions change as far as your understanding of the purpose of the war?
I guess you didn't have any opinions specifically of the president, but how did they change during your experience there?
Well, my opinions of the war changed during the time that I was there.
How did it change, as I was saying?
How did it change?
Well, basically the way it changed was we had captured a North Vietnamese soldier
who had been, prior to being in service, had been a professor of mathematics in Hanoi.
And when we had captured him,
he had agreed to become what was called a Kit Carson scout.
They basically were people that came to work then for us.
And we used them for translators and for intelligence gathering and all that.
Kind of like the Indians with the cavalry back in the old west.
And we were all sitting around one night getting drunk.
And he told me that the only difference
between me and him was that I wanted to go home to the U.S. and chase women, and he wanted to go back north and chase women, and that other than that, we had no difference.
And it dawned on me after a period of time that he was right, that they were just like us, that they weren't communists, they were just people.
And so my attitude became one then, if they were just people, what were we doing here?
And then I began to question what Johnson and Westmoreland said at that time about Johnson's big speeches about the flag in Asia and all that.
And I began to wonder, what is that man talking about?
We really don't even belong here.
Was that during your first tour?
That was probably late in my first tour that I began to wonder, why am I here?
And, okay, I guess just to give us an overview, can you tell, I guess, the dates and place of your three tours?
Okay.
The first time I went over was November the 17th, 1967, and came back September 5th or 6th, I believe, in 68.
Then went back again in late October of 68.
And don't remember when I came back then, but went again in 70 and came back in early 71, like January 71.
Where was I?
I was essentially out based at Da Nang.
I was with the Navy Medical Corps.
And if I recall right, it was the official name was
Medical Headquarters Group out of Da Nang.
And what else?
Where was I?
About three years in Da Nang.
Yes.
Do you know about the way the military works, especially between the Navy and the Marine Corps?
Not really.
I was going to ask you at service.
All right.
I was with the Navy.
The Marine Corps is essentially a part of the Navy.
It operates semi-autonomously.
But in order not to duplicate some services, although they do duplicate other services, like you'll find Navy pilots and Marine Corps pilots, and you'll find...
Marine Corps cooks and Navy cooks, but you will not find Navy medical personnel and Marine Corps medical personnel.
The Marine Corps drafts those personnel from the Navy.
So I was in the Navy, and I was what was called a hospital corpsman, which is what the Army calls a medic.
And so I was
in the Navy, attached to a Navy unit, but loaned out to a Marine Corps unit, so to speak.
So I was, my attachment was with the 1st Marine Division, 5th Marines, which was based out of Da Nang, if I recall.
I think that was their official headquarters.
So you didn't really, did you go into any combat?
Yes, you went, you were attached to a Marine Corps unit
And you went where they went.
And you went however they went.
If they walked, you walked.
If they flew, you flew.
If they went in helicopters, you went in helicopters.
You went in and you came out the same way they did.
Hopefully that was a lie.
But essentially you dressed like they did.
The only difference was that you wore a Marine Corps uniform, but you wore a Navy insignia on it.
Okay.
You looked like them.
You dressed like them.
You moved and ate like them.
You did everything they did except that you were technically a noncombatant.
Did you have training for this?
Yes.
You go through Navy training and then you go through Marine Corps training and then you go where they go.
Okay.
So when I went in, I went through Navy boot camp.
Then I went through Navy hospital school.
Then I went through Marine Corps boot camp.
And then if you were going to go with, say, a specialized unit like a recon team, which would be the equivalent of a Green Beret team, then you went through that special recon training as well.
And then you went wherever they went.
So that's how I got attached to the Marine Corps.
you were, because you were technically a non-combatant, you were issued a weapon for your personal defense.
And you theoretically were not supposed to use this weapon in an offensive or combative role.
You were only supposed to use it just to protect yourself from being killed.
That sidearm, it was a sidearm, it was a .45 pistol.
Most corpsmen that I knew
The weapon was in such sad state of repair that we grabbed whatever weapon we could find after that.
You know, I personally had a .357 revolver, a Smith & Wesson revolver that I carried in a shoulder holster.
But we looked just like Marines.
The only thing was we carried a medical kit.
Now, you've seen the World War II pictures where they had the little red cross and all that, the little arm brassers.
Okay, you were issued those.
but you learned very quickly not to wear those because they made outstanding targets.
So you immediately put the brassard in your pocket or in your medical kit or just flat threw it away and you got something to cover that red cross up on your helmet.
that World War II was much different, or at least what you see in the movies was much different than the way it really went down in Vietnam.
Nobody wore the Red Cross unless they wanted to die.
Okay.
Next, while we're on the subject of the military, what were your opinions of military leadership?
Opinions of military leadership.
Depends on what level.
The very highest level I thought was very ignorant.
They did not know what was going on.
They would come into the country for what was called a commanding general's inspection.
He'd be there three hours.
They'd run him around the base, show him a few things, show him some super-duper weapons, and he'd go home thinking that we were beating the world.
You know, the day-to-day leadership had more experience because they were there.
And they saw the problems, and they saw that the textbook would not always work, or they saw where the textbook would work.
But generally you saw no higher...
Oh, I don't guess I really ever saw much higher than maybe a Marine Corps colonel who was actually on a day-to-day basis.
I'm talking about actually in the field situation.
In the offices back in the headquarters areas, I'm sure they had generals and like that.
It was the field leadership was very wise.
They knew what was going on.
They were out there fighting it with us.
The upper leadership, especially in the case of like General Westmoreland and some of those, I don't think they ever knew what the picture really was.
They had what they thought the picture was, and it was generally fundamentally wrong.
Did you learn this pretty quickly?
Yeah, about the first week or two.
You learn very quickly or you die, you know.
I had my first rude shock about the military the first time that I ever got out of a helicopter.
When we had practice back in the States, the helicopter would come in and it would be like about two feet off the ground and it would stop and everybody would jump out, right?
Okay.
In Vietnam, with people shooting at you, the helicopter maybe got somewhere between 10 or 12 feet from the ground, sometimes closer, and it didn't exactly stop.
It just came to a slow move, and you got out the best way you knew how.
Sometimes they would stop, just depending on what the situation we were in.
Also, when I realized that...
the first time people were actually shooting at you, you know, and that they really weren't afraid of because you weren't American, you know.
That didn't bother them the least bit.
It wasn't like I'm an American, you know, the whole world stops for me.
And you realize that some of your leadership, you know, you're in the middle of a serious firefight.
I mean, you're pinned down.
And this guy says, follow me over the top like John Wayne, and you think, this guy's
out of this hole, you know?
And so you learned real quick or you died.
How did you adapt to your first time there and was this adaptation easier than your second and third?
I mean, was your second and third easier than the first?
Okay, how did I adapt the first time I was there?
The way I adapted the first time that I was there was probably I just flushed out of my mind everything that everybody had taught me and went back to some real basic survival type instincts.
Also had help of a sergeant whose name was Coyne.
He was from, it was kind of really unusual spelling, it was K-O-I-N-N-E, you know.
And he was from New Orleans, and he had been in country for, I don't know, I think at least one tour, probably more.
In fact, I'm pretty sure it was more.
And he decided that for some reason or the other,
that I was too stupid to survive on my own, and that he was going to kind of take me under his wing.
And it's kind of like you see all these movies of a father taking a young son out, teaching him about the woods.
Well, this was kind of what this guy was doing.
He was taking me out and teaching me that, okay, look, I know they taught you this in boot camp.
Let me show you how it really is.
And, you know, I...
I credit that probably with keeping me alive.
He told me that there were times to stand up and run, and there were times to keep your head down and run, and times not to run at all.
And that paid off in my second and third tours in that I managed to get back in at least one piece and alive.
And I would say probably had it not been for him, had it not been from training from someone who had been there and knew the ropes, that I probably would have gotten killed more.
Almost did as it was.
He had some close calls.
Yeah, we had a few.
How did you relate to the South Vietnamese people, and did you have any previous cultural training?
Previous cultural training?
None whatsoever.
How did I relate to the South Vietnamese people?
At first, the South Vietnamese people were...
It's probably like going into any foreign country.
The South Vietnamese people have their own strange way of doing things.
First of all, they're shorter than we are for the most part, so you are a giant wherever you go, which makes you feel pretty good until somebody bigger than you comes along.
They have some unusual ways of doing things, and at first you get the impression that these people are...
that they're stupid, they're backwards.
To some extent, you think that they're a little weird in that... Have you ever read this book, Backfire?
Uh-huh, yeah, I read it.
Okay.

He talks about one of the really things in there that's interesting about South Vietnamese that apparently a good deal of the military never learned was that South Vietnamese men can walk down the street holding hands.
Okay.
Okay.
Well, here, we don't think that's quite so cool.
So, you know, you're sitting there and you're watching this.
You've been in country maybe three or four days, and you're watching these guys walking down the street holding hands.
And you're thinking, these two guys are funny.
Then everybody starts doing it in South Vietnam, and you think the whole country's funny.
After a while, though...
at least in my mind, was that you begin to want to see some of the country and see the customs.
Because, you know, we didn't fight all the time we were there.
I mean, there were times that you would be absolutely bored to tears for two or three weeks at a time.
And then you may be fighting solid two or three weeks at a time.
But for the most part, we didn't fight every day.
That's kind of one of the things that people think that we did, that we fought 24 hours a day, 365 days a year.
We really didn't.
You know, you might be...
two or three weeks, just bored out of your mind, and then have a two or three hour fight.
And then you got liberty, you know, like R&R or, you know, a pass, okay?
And so I went to Saigon.
And I fell in love with my first love in Saigon.
I fell in love with part Chinese, part Vietnamese, part French girl.
And
Because you fall in love, you start learning a whole lot about people and culture, you know, and just the things that you do when you fall in love.
I mean, you know, we would go to markets and stuff, and, you know, I mean, when you're in love, you do whatever that other person wants to do, you know.
And she wanted to go to the market.
Okay, what are you going to do?
You know, you want to be with her?
You go to the market.
And you just can't help but learning things, you know.
And that's where I began first learning about self and these people.
You can also get drunk with them.
They'll tell you a whole lot of good things about them.
We read Backfire for our class.
Do you agree with most of the things that he's saying in the book, or do you have any disagreements with him?
Insofar as he talks about the American attitude toward the war and the notion of American exceptionalism and how that arose, I 100% agree with him on that.
Now, some of the other things about how decisions were made, I'm going to have to assume that he has had benefit of documents that I haven't had.
And so I'd have to assume that he's right, and I really don't have an opinion one way or the other.
What about on our, I guess, total lack of understanding of the entities?
That, for the most part, is true.
Did you see that with other...
Yes, I saw that.
I would say that there were...
Of the soldiers that were in my unit, about 100 soldiers, there were maybe four that really had any kind of understanding of how Vietnam worked at all and how the people lived.
The rest of them just seemed to hate them.
They hated them because we were there.
They hated them because they resisted what we did.
They hated them because it was Tuesday.
They just hated them.
They hated them.
They hated the enemy.
They just hated everything.
There were maybe four or five people in a unit that would either, for whatever reason, would try to understand the Vietnamese and understand
Just understand the culture and the way of life.
Maybe not a particular person, but just understand how can these people be like this and would spend the effort.
Can you understand the frustrations that built up to have something like a My Life or a thing?
I can understand the frustrations that built up.
I can't understand the wholesale killing.
Yes, I can very readily understand the frustrations.
You see, back in the States, prior to the Tet Offensive of 68, y'all were told, the people in the States were told that we were winning the war.
Well, we were told the same thing.
We're in Vietnam fighting the war.
When the Tet Offensive came down, of course, we're there, so we're the first ones to know.
And you don't know what's going on all over the country, but you knew what was happening right where you were at.
And we were getting the hell beat out of us right where I was at.
And so we begin, you know, first of all, we're trying to stay alive.
You're trying to figure out at the same time how this happened.
Try to figure out what's going on, you know.
And then you don't believe your leaders, okay?
You don't believe your leaders.
You don't believe the South Vietnamese because from our experience, they lied to us all the time.
You don't understand why these people don't want to be democratized.
You don't understand why you're there.
You're just frustrated with your military, with the people in the country, and with yourself.
And you're just totally mad at everybody.
So I can understand the frustration.
I can't understand it to the point that I'm going to take a weapon and just go out and just massacre some woman or some children or some old man, you know, as a way to work off my frustrations.
I just don't believe that I could have ever done that.
Did you have any experience with V.C.
Yeah.
The one guy that we captured, the one I was telling you about, he was a VC.
Well, actually, he was an NVA, North Vietnamese Army.
He was a regular, a professional soldier.
VC, we captured, for the most part, the understanding at the VC that I had were that they were, first of all, everybody in Vietnam is basically illiterate.
Not everybody, but for the most part the population is illiterate.
They live off of tradition.
And it is very easy to whip some people into, if you go in to lay some propaganda on them and whip them up.

Since they had been fighting from what they thought was imperialism for many, many years, it was not hard for the NVA to whip them up into thinking that we were just the same imperialistic dogs that the French were.
Some others weren't fighting from this high notion of nationalism.
Some of them were actually impressed.
I mean, the VC or the NBA or VC went out and said, you're now in the military.
You either fight or you die, or we kill your parents, or your mother, father, sister, wife, or whatever.
And so they were kind of forced conscripts.
For the most part, they were generally fairly poorly trained.
fairly bad soldiers, and generally the life of a VC was probably not too long because he was not a professional soldier.
Not that the life of a professional soldier was all that much longer, but I'd say that being made a VC was almost nearly suicide.
Did your opinions of the South Vietnamese change during the war?
No, well, yes, I guess it did.

When I first went over, I didn't know what South Vietnamese was, except that they were about 5'2", and that they had slanted eyes, and they were these little people who talked real funny, and they were being victimized by this mean old communist up north, and that they were kind of backwards and all that.
And so that was what was basically told to us and the impression that I got as I went over.
After I got there, my impression changed.
That impression stayed with me and has not changed to this date.
I think the South Vietnamese people are people just like anybody else.
I think that they have their own way of doing things.
They have their own culture, their own traditions, their own notions of what Vietnam is.
And in that regard, I don't have a change of opinion.
I don't particularly think their way is any better or worse than ours.
I just think it's different.
The only part of the population that I have a worry about is probably the Amerasians, the children of Vietnamese and Americans, that a good deal of them apparently are still in Vietnam.
And I understand that they...
that they're kind of like lepers or treated like lepers, that they make their living by being prostitutes or black marketeers or that the Vietnamese don't like them.
And our soldiers just basically abandoned them.
And I've got some wonders about, on the part of our government, whether or not it's fair to leave those people there.
But then again, what are you going to do about getting them out?
That's the other question.
But no, my opinions towards the South Vietnamese hadn't changed.
Okay, as far as I've read a lot about problems with drugs and then with careerism, do you have any comments about that?
Problems with drugs?
You mean like were there drugs there?
Well, did you see it?
Oh, you bet.
Big time.
Drug use in Vietnam was big time.
There were instances that I saw and that I knew of where, in fact, the South Vietnamese military was the biggest drug pushers in certain areas of anybody.
Also, you've got to consider something about American soldiers and American people.
American people are used to leisure, having things to do.
Football, baseball, tennis, going to...
the Dixie chicken or whatever.
And a lot of times in Vietnam it was miserably boring.
You would spend a couple of three weeks just doing day-to-day mundane chores.
How would you like to spend your entire eight-hour day putting sand into canvas bags and stacking these bags up for your fire camp and then doing that for two or three solid weeks?
So you get kind of bored, right?
And then at night, you get to lay inside of this nifty fire camp that you built and listen to a radio.
And that's about your whole life in Vietnam there for that period while you're in this base camp.
So people have to have something to do.
You're frustrated.
Your life is boring.
You don't know whether you're going to die a minute from now, a week from now, whatever.
So drugs became kind of a way of people
drinking to forget their problems.
Drug usage in certain places was real big.
Certain other places is almost unheard of.
Would I say 50% of American servicemen use drugs or 30% or 10%?
I'd say probably in the younger group, probably 80% or more.
Younger group being 22 or younger, you know.
But that was also the age of people that were drafted, and a good deal of those had come into the service with drug histories at home.
So, you know, I mean, they may have brought some of that with them.
I don't know.
But, yeah, there was a good deal of drug usage.
Okay.
Careerism, I don't know that I know what you mean by careerism.
People wanting to go to Vietnam to put it on their resume that they were an officer.
If they were an officer, going to Vietnam would sometimes get them over the hump.
Everybody knew the war would be over one of these days, and that in peacetime military, it's almost impossible to be promoted beyond a certain level.
So a good deal of these officers would, at least in my line of thinking, would go to Vietnam, serve some rather rinky-dink tour,
You know, but be able to say that, you know, I was in Vietnam and then could progress and rank.

You know, I would say that the under officers or the lower level officers like lieutenants and captains and, you know, like that probably, I would say they're probably some of them that were like ladder climbers, but I'd say for the most part they were doing like the rest of us.
They just wanted to live through it all and get home.
Why did you volunteer for subsequent tours?
Because I was dumb.
Okay.
But how are these tours different from the first as far as seeing a change in the type of combat and then attitudes of soldiers?
Okay.
Why did I volunteer for subsequent tours?
Okay.
I volunteered for kind of a combination of reasons.
One of them was after I'd done my first tour,
I went back to the States, and I went back to, well, I went home on leave.
You know, you get 30 days leave, and I went home.
And my little brother is like a year younger than I am.
And my little brother's got this real John Wayne mentality.
Well, they have this thing in the military that they won't send two sons to a war zone.
They'll let them both be in the service, but they won't send them both to the war zone.
So I pretty much figured my little brother was one of those fools that would run him over the top and do like John Wayne and get himself blown away completely.
So if I went back to Vietnam, he couldn't go because he would be the sole surviving son.
That was one reason.
Another reason was that when I went to the Naval Hospital in San Diego, what was going to be my assigned duty
for the next three years was going to be real mundane tasks.
And I decided that I wasn't going to spend the rest of my career in the military being bored out of my mind.
The third reason was that there was a program that people that would volunteer, they would give you a cut off your enlistment, off your active tour of duty.
Originally, when I volunteered for six years active, I thought, boy, I do not want to be here doing this for the next five years.
So if you volunteer for a tour, they would cut your enlistment like six months or nine months or a year, whatever.
And so for a combination of all those reasons is why I went for the subsequent tours.
What were the differences?
Oh, probably...
differences?
Well, in 67 we thought we were winning.
After 68 we knew we weren't.
We had heard discussions about the truce talks and the peace talks and everything.
And we figured that sooner or later that somebody was going to come up with some kind of peaceful deals and we could get out of Vietnam.
And so basically we just sort of fought defensively then.
All we wanted to do was
Keep up from killing us.
We weren't really so worried about whether we were going to win or whether we were going to lose.
We just didn't want to die.
And just keep our head down, do your tour, and go home.
It's like going to see a bad movie.
You just want to get the thing over with so that you can leave.
So that was about it.
the attitude.
Now, I mean, that's not to say that we didn't try to fight battles.

A lot of times you would have to fight a battle, and you would have to try to win just to stay alive, but I think the attitude was not so much one of winning as much as it was just trying to stay alive.
Okay, what about as far as the attitudes of the people that were there?
You mean American soldiers that were there?
Yeah, yeah.
Pretty much everybody had the same attitude, you know.
We had what we called...
base camp commandos who were these guys that would do the John Wayne bit.
And pretty much everybody made fun of them and tried to stay away from them because that was the kind of guy that'd get you killed.
The rest of us took care of each other.
You take care of me, I take care of you.
We just try to keep each other alive until you can go home.
Nobody really wanted to fight because everybody really thought it was kind of futile.
We weren't winning.
We weren't going to win.
All we wanted to do was do our 11 months and go home and try to get home in one piece.
You really thought that you weren't going to win?
No.
After the 68 test, I don't think that anybody really thought we would win.
except for maybe the military leaders.

I would say that the average soldier, I'm talking about average actual real combat soldier, a guy that was actually out there shooting, I would think that he probably figured that the best we could do was fight to a draw.
You know, that given the political situation at home and...
you know, given the curtailment on the military that the best we could hope for was a drop.
Now, we all thought that we could win, you know, that we had the stuff, you know, to win if we were allowed to win.
But we felt like we weren't allowed to win.
How do you mean?
Well, we felt like the military and the government back home was actually hampering us with this notion of limited war.
Because they talked about limited bombing of the North.
Our feeling was that you either go out and you fight a real war or you don't fight a war.
That there's no such thing as a limited fight.
Kind of goes back to the notion of like, did you ever get in fights when you were a little kid?
When I was a little kid, the way you fought was you always fought the guy.
And if you knocked him on the ground, you didn't jump on top of him.
You let him get back up.
Or you never hit below the belt.
That's limited war.
What really happens?
Generally, if you knock the guy down, you pile in on top of him because now you've got the advantage and you're going to beat his brains out.
And if he's piled all over you, you forget about hitting below the belt.
You hit him wherever you can hit him.

Well, that's what we felt like, that these rules were placed on us, that they were like those rules, that either we were really going to fight or we were just going to go home, that given the situation, the best we could hope for was just a draw.
So since we weren't going to win,
And presumably we weren't going to lose.
We were just going to drop.
There was no real reason to go out and really do anything because you're liable to get yourself killed.
And the whole idea was to stay alive and go home.
What would you have preferred that we had done as far as military strategy?
Not gotten there in the first place.
In 65 or 66, I believe it was, the...
I believe it was the Marine Corps had a strategy that I think the Army popularized it really.
It was called search and destroy.
And we would basically sweep in on a known or what was supposed to be known VC area.
And they would come in like a big pair of pliers and they would just close those pliers down.
And they would destroy the military village at a fight of the VC.
And if that meant burning the food, burning the village, or actually we didn't just burn the village, we burned anything that would be of any military value to the VC.
One of the cute things that I thought was that we also burned the food, or we poisoned it.
While it was also of military value to the VC, it was the people in the villages whose food we were tearing up.
I always thought, well, that's kind of unusual to me, that we're going to whip the VC by whipping the civilian populace.
I mean, if it was like an area that was a known B.C.
holdup, we would have this plier movement, and we would just pinch them in, close them in, and then just squeeze it down until we choked the military fighting ability out of them.
That meant killing all of them, and that was what you had to do.
And it depended on who you got around.
If it was the B.C., you might get him to surrender.
If it was a North Vietnamese regular, you were pretty much going to have to kill him.
He was a good soldier.
He was a professional soldier, and he was not going to give up.
It's kind of like the picture of the Japanese kamikaze guys during World War II.
The North Vietnamese soldier was so well trained and so well disciplined that you were probably going to have to kill him.
You were not going to get him to give up.
Did you feel as though the American government and top military people did not realize that the North Vietnamese were not going to give up with the policy of attrition and those kinds of ideas?
Did I think that that's what they thought?
Yeah, that's very definitely what I think they thought.
I do not think that our government, with the exception of maybe a few people, but I think they were in the minority.
I think that they felt that Westmoreland's
war of attrition would eventually work.
And I think that, I believe it was General Jopp, or maybe it was Ho, who many years before had said that he would fight.
How long did we want to fight?
10 years?
20 years?
50 years?
They would fight however long we wanted to fight, and in the end, they would win.
And I think we should have read Ho's book a lot closer than we did.
They were going to win.
Either that or we were going to have to physically go into North Vietnam and just take the war to them and destroy them.
Do you think that we should have gone into North Vietnam?
Well, it depends.
It depends on whether you want to look at it from the military point of view or whether you want to look at it on the moralistic point of view.
If you want to look at it on the military point of view in that
To win this war, we've got to go into Vietnam.
We're not going to consider the moral aspect of whether we've been there or not.
Yes, we should have gone into North Vietnam.
Even with the prospect of China?
I don't really think that the prospect of China was quite as much as everybody made it out to be, especially it seems to me.
Now, there were a good deal of Chinese weaponry, but I think that was really kind of overblown.

And some stuff that I've heard subsequent from some people that were relatively believable military people have said that the notion of China coming into the war was much larger than China's real ability to get into the war.
I don't think that they would have actually committed the ravaging forces like they did or are supposed to have done in Korea.
From the military point of view, yes, I think we should have gone into the north.
From the moralistic point of view, I don't think we should have ever got there in the beginning.
I think we should have listened to the French and should have read Ho's book.
I think we should have just basically stayed home.
Well, I guess it has to do with my question as far as, did you feel when you first went over there that we were justified in being there?
And when did you change your mind?
When I went there, yes, I felt we were justified.
Because I didn't know any better.
I mean, I listened to Lyndon Johnson and all the people back home.
The draft Dodger bit and all this.
There's this cultural engravement in people.
Do you want your parents to think that you're a draft dodger?
Do you want to have to leave your country and go to Canada?
Or do you want to go to prison?
Those are some questions you have to ask.
But on the other hand, when we went and when I went and the people that I went with,

We got there, and for the first little while, some people it took longer, some people it took a very short time, some people never learned it, and some people was that we really thought we were doing the right thing.
I mean, people have asked me, why did you ever go to Vietnam?
I went to Vietnam because I thought I was doing the right thing.
When I was in Vietnam, my job was a medic.
All I wanted to do was I wanted to make sure that this soldier, that I kept him alive so that he could go home.
I wanted to be the very best medic that the United States military ever had.
I wanted to do my job because I thought it was right.
It took a little while for me to figure out that it wasn't quite right, but at first we went because we really thought that was the right thing.
And we were proud.
And I mean, we were really proud.
We thought that we were fighting communists, making these people free.
And that's what we really believed.
I had some friends who were in ships off the coast that were just bombarding the hell out of Vietnam.
We would talk to them, and they really thought they were doing the right thing.
We all really thought we were doing the right thing.
I think that probably changed
After the Tet, we began to wonder, what the hell are we doing?
And then later, as the war drug on, I think the attitude was really just, I'm caught up in the system.
I just want to do my time and go.
Even the people that were coming there for the first time, just initially?
That's kind of a real iffy one.
Some of them really thought they were doing the right thing.
Some of them thought, oh my God, this is my worst nightmare.
Some of them really thought they were doing the wrong thing, that they had been caught up in the system and that they couldn't fight the system.
I'd say probably the first attitude.
You could always tell when a new guy came into your camp or something.
He was the guy that was going to make the world a safer democracy, kill communists and all that.
You thought, oh my God, let me get away from this guy.
He's going to get me killed.
You know?
But I'd say that probably 1970 the attitude was just do your time and go.
Did you see any racial problems?
Yeah.
You're talking about between American soldiers?
Blacks.
Blacks and whites, yes.
There was a good deal of racial problems.
Why, I never really understand.
There was just a good deal of it.
I really don't understand why, to tell you the truth.
I never really thought about it.
I just know that it existed.
Fighting?
There would be some fighting sometimes, but you've got to understand, people in the military, if they don't have anybody else to fight, they'll fight amongst themselves, too.
So, I mean, you had to discount it somewhat there.
There was...
I don't think there was any like...
Anybody that would want to just fight just because this guy was black.
Although there may have been, you know.
I really never thought about it, you know.
I know it existed.
I saw fighting between the races.
I saw lots of racial slurs.
I saw Confederate flags.
You know, I just really never thought about why.
What type of reactions from the public, your family, and your friends did you receive when I came home?
Not real good.
Oh, that's great.
I can remember when I came back, I was in San Francisco, and we were in the airport, and, you know, we were in our uniform and all that, and, you know,
We thought it was going to be like at the end of World War II.
America's soldiers coming home.
We're going to get ticker tape.
People are going to be proud of us.
I remember a girl that walked up to me.
Like I said, I was a medic.
She walked up and she was extremely belligerent.
And she kept asking, how many people did you kill?
How many babies did you burn?
How many women did you ban?
How many women did you rape?
And I thought, what the hell is this woman talking about?
And then the attitude was a lot more.
My family, you know.
My mother was real proud.
Her boy had made it home for one reason.
She would take me around to see all her friends.
All I just wanted to do was quiet time.
She would take me around to see all her friends like a little animal in a zoo or something.
Some of them would be happy and some of them would look at me like this is one of them killers over there.
